newsitem.title: USA: Parents of jailed American in Peru protest ceremony.
newsitem.headline: Parents of jailed American in Peru protest ceremony.

text.p: While the daughter of Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori graduated from Boston University on Sunday, outside the ceremonies the parents of an American jailed in Peru demanded a fair trial for their daughter.

The father of Lori Berenson, 27, who was sentenced to life in prison in January 1996 for being a leader of a Peruvian rebel force, wished Keiko Fujimori well, but asked that she apply her studies at home.

"She has had the opportunity to study in the cradle of democracy. I hope she learned her lessons in (political science) 101 well, because she has a lot to take home with her," Mark Berenson told reporters.

Lori Berenson was sentenced by a secret military court for treason and being a leader of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA), the group that held hostages in the Japanese ambassador's residence for more than four months until April.
The Clinton administration, more than 100 members of Congress and former U.S. President Jimmy Carter have all backed a new trial for her.
Berenson's parents, other family members and a handful of friends held up placards with Lori's face outside Boston's Nickerson Field, where the commencement was held under sunny skies on Sunday.
A separate group of about 30 protesters demonstrated against alleged human rights abuses in Peru.

Keiko Fujimori, who has acted as Peru's first lady since Fujimori's split from his wife in 1995, graduated with a bachelor's degree in business administration. Her father was scheduled to be among the thousands of guests at the graduation ceremonies.
Lori Berenson has been held in a dark, cold prison and denied visits from the International Red Cross and her lawyers for months and her health has deteriorated, her father said.
"She's been in a dimly lit cell for 4-1/2 months and she's having trouble focusing her eyes," he told Reuters.
The cell, where the temperatures reach a high of just 40 degrees (4 Celsius) and dip to as low as five degrees (-15 C), has nearly crippled her hands, Berenson said.
"She lives in a refrigerator. She has the hands of an 80 year old. They are gnarled and twisted. They are grotesque," he said.
Berenson said his daughter was never a member of the MRTA and said Fujimori should live up to the ideals of democracy and grant her a fair trial.

A Jesuit priest who was among the hostages in the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima said in the commencement address at the university that a "lasting peace" to the problems in Peru or elsewhere "is never won with bullets."

"A lasting peace can be achieved only through working to advance justice in a real democracy, respecting individuals and also institutions, incorporating everybody in a common effort to achieve meaningful human development," Father Juan Julio Wicht said.
